downloadJSAtOnload, false);\n\t\t\telse if (window.attachEvent)\n\t\t\twindow.attachEvent(\"onload\", downloadJSAtOnload);\n\t\t\telse window.onload = downloadJSAtOnload;\n\t\t\t}\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n\t\t\tDeferJS(\"https://d1bxh8uas1mnw7.cloudfront.net/assets/embed.js\");\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n\t\t\tDeferJS(\"https://d1bxh8uas1mnw7.cloudfront.net/assets/embed.js\");\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Gravitationally Lensed Quasar SDSS J1442+4055: Redshifts of Lensing Galaxies, Time Delay, Microlensing Variability, and Intervening Metal System at <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a02</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Vyacheslav N. Shalyapin</span><sup>1,2,3</sup></span> and <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Luis J. Goicoechea</span><sup>2</sup><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0110-834X\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0110-834X\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg></a></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2019 March 12</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2019.        <div class=\"print-hide content-tools\">\n\t\t\t<div>\n\t<p>\n\t\t<span id=\"total-downloads\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-total-dwnlds\"><b>204</b> Total downloads</span>\n\t\t\t<br J1442+4055)\n\t\t\t</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F873%2F2%2F117\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/873/2/117</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>We present <I>r</I>-band photometric monitoring of the two images, A and B, of the gravitationally lensed quasar SDSS J1442+4055 using the Liverpool Telescope (LT). From the LT light curves between 2015 December and 2018 August, we derive at once a time delay of 25.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.5 days (1<I>\u03c3</I> confidence interval; A is leading) and microlensing magnification gradients below 10<SUP>\u22124</SUP> mag day<SUP>\u22121</SUP>. The delay interval is not expected to be affected by an appreciable microlensing-induced bias, so it can be used to estimate cosmological parameters. This paper also focuses on new Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC) and LT spectroscopic observations of the lens system. We determine the redshift of two bright galaxies around the doubly imaged quasar using LT spectroscopy, while GTC data lead to low-noise individual spectra of A, B, and the main lensing galaxy, G1. The G1 spectral shape is accurately matched to an early-type galaxy template at <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a00.284, and it has potential for further relevant studies. Additionally, the quasar spectra show absorption by metal-rich gas at <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a02. This dusty absorber is responsible for an extinction bump at a rest-frame wavelength of 2209\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02 \u00c5, which has strengths of ~0.47 and 0.76 mag <I>\u03bc</I>m<SUP>\u22121</SUP> for A and B, respectively. In such an intervening system, the dust-to-gas ratio, gas-phase metallicity indicator [Zn/H], and dust depletion level [Fe/Zn] are relatively high.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/873/2/117&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/873/2/117&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJ...873..117S\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2019ApJ...873..117S&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2019ApJ...873..117S\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab08f0s1\" name=\"apjab08f0s1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Gravitationally lensed quasars are becoming essential tools to study the structure and composition of galaxies at different redshifts and of the entire universe (Schneider et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib57\">2006</a>; Treu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib65\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib65\">2010</a>). Hence, significant effort is being devoted to the discovery of lensed quasars and their follow-up observations. For example, the current archive of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib71\">2000</a>) includes photometric and spectroscopic data of more than 500,000 quasars (P\u00e2ris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib53\">2018</a>). The SDSS database contains a large collection of quasar spectra taken as part of the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS; Dawson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib11\">2013</a>), and More et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib49\">2016</a>) took advantage of this fact to find 13 new double quasars. Other ongoing projects are also reporting discoveries of double/quadruple quasars and lists of lensed quasar candidates (e.g., Anguita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib2\">2018</a>; Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib34\">2018</a>; Lemon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib39\">2018</a>). In addition, new multiple quasars must be fully characterized by follow-up observations. Detailed spectroscopy is used to identify intervening objects, analyze their gas, dust, and stellar content, and put constraints on the size and structure of sources through microlensing-induced spectral distortions (e.g., Wucknitz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib70\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib70\">2003</a>; Sluse et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib60\">2007</a>; Mediavilla et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib46\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib46\">2011</a>; Goicoechea &amp; Shalyapin <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib23\">2016</a>). Light curves of lensed quasars are also key pieces to determine time delays and constrain cosmological parameters (e.g., Vuissoz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib68\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib68\">2008</a>; Bonvin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib6\">2017</a>; Shalyapin &amp; Goicoechea <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib59\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib59\">2017</a>) and/or detect microlensing variability and thus learn about the structure of quasars and the composition of lensing galaxies (e.g., Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib32\">2004</a>; Sluse et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib61\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib61\">2011</a>; Hainline et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib25\">2013</a>).</p><p>After performing data mining to identify double-quasar candidates in the SDSS-III DR10 (Ahn et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib1\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib1\">2014</a>; P\u00e2ris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib52\">2014</a>), complementary observations of some of these candidates allowed Sergeyev et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>) to find the new optically bright, wide-separation double quasar SDSS J1442+4055 (see also More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib49\">2016</a>). From a medium-resolution SDSS-BOSS spectrum of the A image of SDSS J1442+4055, P\u00e2ris et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib52\">2014</a>) presented several estimates of the source (quasar) redshift. While the SDSS pipeline produced <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.5746\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002, a principal component analysis led to <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.5931\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0006. After a visual inspection, P\u00e2ris et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib52\">2014</a>) indicated that <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.593, and we adopt this value throughout the paper. The lens system basically consists of two quasar images (A and B) having <em>r</em>\u00a0~\u00a018\u221219 mag and separated by 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />156, as well as the main lensing galaxy (G1; <em>r</em>\u00a0~\u00a019.5 mag), located 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />38 from the A image, and two additional intervening objects, a secondary galaxy (G2; <em>r</em>\u00a0~\u00a019.8 mag) in the vicinity of G1 and an absorber at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.946 (Sergeyev et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>).</p><p>This paper is dedicated to describing and deeply analyzing follow-up observations of SDSS J1442+4055. In the framework of the Gravitational LENses and DArk MAtter (GLENDAMA) project (Gil-Merino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib22\">2018</a>), in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s2\">2</a>, we present a 2.7 yr photometric monitoring with the 2.0 m Liverpool Telescope (LT) in the <em>r</em> band and associated light curves for both quasar images, as well as spectroscopic observations with the 10.4 m Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC) and the LT. The high signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) spectroscopy over a wide wavelength interval with the GTC allows us to accurately identify the primary lensing galaxy, G1, while we use the LT spectroscopic data of two bright secondary galaxies (G2 and another object in the field around the quasar) to measure their redshifts. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s3\">3</a>, the cross-correlation between the LT light curves of A and B yields the time delay in the lens system. The <em>r</em>-band microlensing variability is also discussed in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s3\">3</a>. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s4\">4</a>, using the GTC spectra of A and B, we reveal the origin of the flux ratios <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> from near-UV to near-IR. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5\">5</a>, we study in detail the intervening gas at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 and its connection with dust at the same redshift. In addition to the GTC and SDSS-BOSS spectra, this analysis is also based on data from the MMT Observatory, i.e., the medium-resolution UV-visible spectra (blueward of 6000 \u00c5) of the two quasar images with moderate S/N (Findlay et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib18\">2018</a>). Our main results and conclusions are summarized in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s6\">6</a>.</p><p>When we were completing our third monitoring season and this work, Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>) presented and analyzed Keck spectra of SDSS J1442+4055. In this paper, their spectroscopic results are compared to ours.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab08f0s2\" name=\"apjab08f0s2\">2.\u00a0Observations and Data Reduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s2-1\" name=\"apjab08f0s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0LT-IO:O Photometric Monitoring</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We have monitored the double quasar SDSS J1442+4055 over three complete observing seasons from 2015 December 23 to 2018 August 28. This monitoring suffers from two visibility gaps of about 4 months, which are not important in determining the relatively short time delay between images (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s3\">3</a>). All photometric observations were made in the <em>r</em> band with the IO:O camera on the LT. With 2\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a02 binning (pixel scale of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />30), we obtained frames of the lensed quasar for 135 observing epochs (nights). For the first 7 nights, we took two consecutive exposures of 250 s each, while 4\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0150 s exposures were obtained on every remaining night. Thus, we collected 526 individual frames of 150 or 250 s. The LT pipeline performed a primary data reduction, including bias subtraction, overscan trimming, and flat-fielding. Additionally, we interpolated over bad pixels and removed cosmic rays.</p><p>In order to extract fluxes for the two quasar images, we used the IMFITFITS software (McLeod et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib44\">1998</a>). From this tool, assuming reasonable brightness profiles for the lensing galaxies G1 and G2, one can determine the fluxes of A and B through point-spread function (PSF) fitting. The brightness of the main deflector G1 was modeled as a de Vaucouleurs profile (More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib49\">2016</a>), whereas we take an exponential profile to model the light distribution of the secondary lens, G2, since the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) archive includes an image of G2 showing the presence of a disk and spiral arms<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab08f0fn1\">4</a></sup>\n (see the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f1\">1</a>). Both profiles were then convolved with the empirical PSF from the close star at R.A. (J2000)\u00a0=\u00a0220<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />706485 and decl. (J2000)\u00a0=\u00a0+40<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />922076 (<em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a016.075 mag; see the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f1\">1</a>). This PSF star was also used to model the point-like sources A and B. The relative positions of B and G1 (with respect to A), as well as the ellipticity, orientation, and effective radius of G1, were taken from Sergeyev et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>). In addition, the ellipticity and orientation of G2 were set to their values in the SDSS database. In a first iteration, the fluxes of G1 and G2 and the relative position and effective radius of G2 were estimated from the best frames in terms of S/N and FWHM seeing. In a second iteration, we applied the code to all individual frames, allowing the position of A, the background level, and the fluxes of A and B to be free. We also calculated PSF fluxes for a field (control) star that is located at R.A. (J2000)\u00a0=\u00a0220<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />741396 and decl. (J2000)\u00a0=\u00a0+40<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />949647 (<em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a015.998 mag; see the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f1\">1</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> and LT imaging of SDSS J1442+4055. Left: <em>HST</em>-WFC3-G280 zeroth-order frame of size <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn1.gif\" alt=\"$10^{\\prime\\prime} \\times 10^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10^{\\prime\\prime} \\times 10^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span>. Right: first LT-IO:O <em>r</em>-band frame on 2015 December 22. This covers a field of view of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn2.gif\" alt=\"$200^{\\prime\\prime} \\times 200^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">200^{\\prime\\prime} \\times 200^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span> and includes the PSF star and the control star (see main text).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab08f0f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab08f0f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The quasar light curves (<em>r</em>-SDSS magnitudes) show anomalous results for 51 individual frames. These frames producing outliers are characterized by high FWHM seeing, low S/N for A, or tracking/guiding errors (very elongated or trailed stars); thus, we removed them from the final database. The remaining 475 frames represent 90% of the individual observations and have a median FWHM of 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />28. We then combined magnitudes measured on the same night to obtain final photometric data at 135 epochs. To estimate typical photometric errors in the light curves of A, B, and the control star, we used deviations between magnitudes having time separations \u22643 days. This statistical analysis led to uncertainties of 0.0051 (A), 0.0093 (B), and 0.0046 (star) mag, which were multiplied by the relative S/N at each epoch, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"$\\left\\langle {\\rm{S}}/{\\rm{N}}\\right\\rangle $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\left\\langle {\\rm{S}}/{\\rm{N}}\\right\\rangle</script></span></span>/S/N, to calculate errors on a nightly basis (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"$\\left\\langle {\\rm{S}}/{\\rm{N}}\\right\\rangle $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\left\\langle {\\rm{S}}/{\\rm{N}}\\right\\rangle</script></span></span> is the average S/N; Howell <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib29\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib29\">2006</a>). Our final light curves of A, B, and the star are available in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t1\">1</a> and shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f2\">2</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0LT-IO:O <em>r</em>-band light curves of A, B, and the control star. The curves of B and the star are shifted by \u22120.87 and +2.3 mag, respectively, to facilitate comparison. The vertical dotted line corresponds to the epoch of our spectroscopic observations with GTC-OSIRIS (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s2-2\">2.2</a>), while the horizontal dashed line represents the constant flux of the control star.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab08f0f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab08f0f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nLT-IO:O <em>r</em>-band Light Curves of SDSS J1442+4055AB\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\" data-art-data=\"item\" data-art-data-type=\"mrt\"><colgroup><col rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">7,379.288</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.076</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">19.008</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.009</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">15.998</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.004</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">7,398.293</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.029</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.006</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">19.012</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.012</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">15.993</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.006</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">7,400.289</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.022</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.006</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">19.018</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.011</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">16.000</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.005</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">7,406.279</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.026</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.998</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.009</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">15.993</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.005</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">7,412.267</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.034</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.007</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">18.982</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.012</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">15.994</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.006</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab08f0t1fna\" id=\"apjab08f0t1fna\"></a><sup> a</sup><em>r</em>-SDSS magnitude.\n<a name=\"apjab08f0t1fnb\" id=\"apjab08f0t1fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>We use S to denote the field (control) star.\n\n\n\n<p>Only a portion of this table is shown here to demonstrate its form and content. A <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t1_mrt.txt\">machine-readable</a> version of the full table is available.</p>\n\n\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-table-data\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t1_mrt.txt\" target=\"_blank\">Data</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s2-2\" name=\"apjab08f0s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0GTC-OSIRIS Spectroscopy</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We performed spectroscopic observations of SDSS J1442+4055 on 2016 March 5 using the OSIRIS instrument on the GTC. We took a 2850 (3\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0950) s GTC-OSIRIS exposure with each of two grisms, R500B and R500R, and used IRAF<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab08f0fn2\">5</a></sup>\n packages to carry out data reductions. All 950 s subexposures were obtained in dark time, at low air masses, and under good seeing conditions. The average values of the air mass and the FWHM seeing at 6225 \u00c5 amounted to 1.03 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />89, respectively. Regarding the dispersions, they were close to the nominal ones: <em>D</em>(R500B)\u00a0=\u00a03.560 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>D</em>(R500R)\u00a0=4.814 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. However, we slightly modified the standard wavelength ranges, decreasing the minimum wavelength for R500B (3425 \u00c5; to include relevant absorption features) and the maximum wavelength for R500R (9255 \u00c5; to avoid fringing and second-order contamination). The spatial pixel scale was 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />254.</p><p>In order to extract spectra of all individual sources in the strong lensing region, the 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />23 wide slit was oriented along the line joining A and B, and we followed a technique similar to those in our previous analyses of GTC-OSIRIS spectroscopic data (e.g., Goicoechea &amp; Shalyapin <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib23\">2016</a>). We modeled the lens system as a 2D light distribution consisting of two point-like sources (A and B) and a circular de Vaucouleurs profile with <em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />59 (G1), whose relative positions are given in Table 2 of Sergeyev et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>). Such an ideal model was then convolved with a 2D Moffat PSF having a power index <em>\u03b2</em>\u00a0=\u00a03, masked with the slit transmission, and integrated across the slit. Apart from the position of A and the FWHM value, our 1D model at each wavelength bin included the fluxes of A, B, and G1 as free parameters; thus, fits to the GTC-OSIRIS 1D data allowed us to obtain the spectra of the two quasar images and the main lensing galaxy. For each source, in addition to wavelength-dependent fluxes <em>F</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub>, we estimated flux errors <em>eF</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> using Equation (9) of Horne (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib28\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib28\">1986</a>). This method for extracting individual spectra is significantly different from the technique used by Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>), who considered Keck-LRIS observations in the wavelength range 3600\u20138650 \u00c5 on 2016 June 5, extracted data of A and B that are contaminated by light from G1, and then fitted templates for the intrinsic spectral slopes of A, B, and G1 and the supposed reddening of A and B arising from dust in the absorber at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.946 (we justify this hypothesis in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s4\">4</a>).</p><p>We also checked our wavelength and flux calibrations, which were based on HgAr and Ne arc lamp exposures, as well as spectra of the standard star Hilt 600 (Hamuy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib26\">1992</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib27\">1994</a>). First, we compared the positions of narrow absorption lines in the GTC-OSIRIS spectra of A and the SDSS-BOSS spectrum of the brightest quasar image, taken on 2012 May 29. This comparison allowed detection of systematic deviations in our wavelength zero-points, so the R500B and R500R data were shifted by +1.5 and \u22122.0 \u00c5, respectively. Second, we used <em>r</em>-band frames taken with the LT on 2016 March 4 to measure the <em>r</em>-band fluxes of A and B and compare them to the corresponding GTC-OSIRIS fluxes. These spectral fluxes agreed well with the LT photometry (typical deviation of ~1%), so the spectral energy distributions were not rescaled. The final calibrated spectra of A, B, and G1 are included in Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t2\">2</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t3\">3</a>. In addition, the results from the observations with both grisms are plotted in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f3\">3</a>. It is also worth mentioning that the spectral shapes of A and B in the wavelength range 3500\u20136000 \u00c5 are consistent with those obtained with the <em>HST-</em>WFC3 G280 grism on 2016 April 21, i.e., about 7 weeks later (Lusso et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib41\">2018</a>). All raw and reduced frames in FITS format are publicly available at the GTC archive.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab08f0fn3\">6</a></sup>\n\n</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0GTC-OSIRIS spectra of SDSS J1442+4055ABG1 in 2016 March. Top: R500B (left) and R500R (right) spectra of the three sources in the strong lensing region. Vertical dotted lines indicate emission lines at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.593, while gray highlighted regions are associated with atmospheric artifacts. Bottom: R500B (left) and R500R (right) spectra of the primary lensing galaxy. These two panels display zoomed-in versions of the G1 spectra along with the redshifted (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.284) SDSS spectral template of an early-type galaxy. Vertical dashed lines are associated with absorption features.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table
