name=\"apjab08f0t7fna\" id=\"apjab08f0t7fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Central rest-frame wavelength in \u00c5.\n<a name=\"apjab08f0t7fnb\" id=\"apjab08f0t7fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Rest-frame EW in \u00c5.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t7_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t7_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>As a first approximation, EW<sub>B</sub>/EW<sub>A</sub> ratios were used to estimate relative amounts of neutral hydrogen and metals along the two sight lines (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f9\">9</a>). These quantities approximately represent column density ratios <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span> at low optical depths, but they describe <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"$({N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}{)}^{1/2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}{)}^{1/2}</script></span></span> values at very high optical depths (e.g., Draine <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib13\">2011</a>). Thus, in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f9\">9</a>, we have to remark that EW<sub>B</sub> (H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/EW<sub>A</sub> (H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~ <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"$[{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">[{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"${]}^{1/2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{]}^{1/2}</script></span></span>. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5-2\">5.2</a> provides data for a reliable estimation of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f9\">9</a>, we differentiate between neutral atoms (blue circles), low-ionization metals (green circles), and high-ionization metals (red circles).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0EW ratios. We highlight absorption features blueward of the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> emission of the quasar (gray region), because some of them could be blended with lines belonging to the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> forest. Blue, green, and red circles denote ratios of neutral atoms, low-ionization metals, and high-ionization metals, respectively.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab08f0f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab08f0f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1560 and 1656 absorption lines (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t7\">7</a>) are formed at relatively low optical depths, so their EW ratios roughly correspond to column density ratios. We thus obtain that the neutral-carbon column density for B (the most reddened image) is appreciably higher than that for A. From the Keck-HIRES high-resolution spectra, Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>) also found an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ratio above 3. Even though both images seem to be affected by similar amounts of Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, the Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption is stronger along the line of sight to B. Nonrefractory (volatile) elements, e.g., Zn, condense onto dust grains much more difficultly than refractory elements, e.g., Fe and Mg. Hence, in the B image, we observe a relative excess of Zn in the gas phase. However, there are no gas-phase excesses of Fe and Mg, which are more easily trapped in dust grains. It is also clear that the A image is more affected by high-ionization metals.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s5-5\" name=\"apjab08f0s5-5\">5.5.\u00a0Metallicity and Dust Depletion</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The two absorption lines of Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 1608 and Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026 are not saturated and lie outside the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> forest. Thus, we initially used Equation (9.15) of Draine (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib13\">2011</a>) to estimate column densities from their EWs. However, if the column densities are not actually proportional to the EWs (the optically thin regime condition is not met), the <em>N</em> values are underestimated, being underestimated greater when the EW is larger. While the EWs of the Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026 line do not exceed 0.3 \u00c5, the EWs of the Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 1608 line reach 0.6 \u00c5, and we carried out a more detailed analysis of this stronger absorption. For the A image, the optically thin regime approach led to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>)\u00a0=\u00a014.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01. Additionally, the SDSS-BOSS spectrum of A allowed us to construct the curve of growth for Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, as well as to fit the two relevant parameters: <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>)\u00a0=\u00a014.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04 and <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a069\u00a0\u00b13 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We adopted this last interval for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) and considered a bias of \u22120.08 to correct our initial estimate of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) through the optically thin regime approach (its error was also set to 0.04; see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t8\">8</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t8\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 8.</b>\u00a0\nFe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> Column Densities\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0t8\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t8_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 8\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Ion</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>\n<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn85.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>\n<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">14.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">14.74\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">12.97\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">13.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab08f0t8fna\" id=\"apjab08f0t8fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Column density <em>N</em> in cm<sup>\u22122</sup>.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t8_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t8_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>In Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t9\">9</a>, we also present the metal abundances [Fe/H] and [Zn/H], where [X/H]\u00a0=\u00a0log[<em>N</em>(X)/<em>N</em>(H)] \u2212 log(X/H)<sub>\u2609</sub>. We assumed that <em>N</em>(Fe)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>N</em>(Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>), <em>N</em>(Zn)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>N</em>(Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>), and <em>N</em>(H)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) and took the solar abundances log(X/H)<sub>\u2609</sub> from Asplund et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib3\">2009</a>). Using the average value of [Zn/H] as a metallicity estimator (Zn basically remains in the gas phase), the IMS has a supersolar metallicity [Zn/H]<sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0+0.27. This means that (Zn/H)<sub>IMS</sub> is about 2 times (Zn/H)<sub>\u2609</sub>. However, we should bear in mind that Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>) detected H<sub>2</sub> along both lines of sight, so that when using the total hydrogen column density instead of <em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn86.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(H) must be increased by about 1%. As a result, [Zn/H<sub>T</sub>]<sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0~\u00a0+0.07, which confirms the metallicity from sulfur and total hydrogen [S/H<sub>T</sub> ]<sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0~\u00a00, based on high-resolution Keck-HIRES spectra. In addition, the [Fe/H] values are significantly less than zero, indicating depletion of refractory elements onto dust grains. The abundance ratio of iron to zinc, [Fe/Zn], is commonly used as a dust depletion estimator. It measures the depletion of Fe from its gas phase to the dust phase. The column densities in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t8\">8</a> and solar metal abundances in Table 1 of Asplund et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib3\">2009</a>) yielded [Fe/Zn]<sub>A</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11 and [Fe/Zn]<sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.38\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11, where log(Fe/Zn)<sub>\u2609</sub> was averaged over its photosphere and meteorite values.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t9\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 9.</b>\u00a0\nFe and Zn Abundances Relative to Their Solar Values\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0t9\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t9_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 9\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"2\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">[Fe/H]</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"2\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">[Zn/H]</th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">A</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">B</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">A</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">B</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Photosphere</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">\u22120.93\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">\u22121.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">+0.27\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">+0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Meteorites</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">\u22120.88\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">\u22121.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">+0.20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">+0.27\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong> We consider solar photosphere and meteorite metal abundances in Table 1 of Asplund et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib3\">2009</a>).</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t9_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t9_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>The IMS of SDSS J1442+4055 belongs to the family of 2175 \u00c5 dust absorbers (2DAs) that was studied by Ma et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib42\">2018</a>), who also assumed <em>N</em>(H)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>). The 2DAs contain C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> absorbing gas with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn87.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0&gt;\u00a014.0 (we obtain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn88.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) &gt;14.0 from the EWs of the C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1656 line in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t7\">7</a>), and the subDLAs/DLAs with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn89.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~20.0\u201320.5 (subset of the 2DA population) have supersolar metallicities (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t9\">9</a>). These 2DAs also show a strong correlation between dust-to-gas ratio and metallicity. For the dust-to-gas ratio of the IMS (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5-3\">5.3</a>), Equation (7) of Ma et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib42\">2018</a>) predicts a high metallicity, [Zn/H]\u00a0~\u00a0+0.3, in good agreement with the values in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t9\">9</a>. In addition, if we focus on the 2DAs with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn90.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~20.0\u201320.5, their high depletion levels agree well with our measures of [Fe/Zn] (see above). The values of [Fe/Zn]<sub>A</sub> and [Fe/Zn]<sub>B</sub> can be used to estimate the stellar mass of the IMS. From the mass\u2013metallicity\u2013redshift relation of M\u00f8ller et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib48\">2013</a>) and the observed [Zn/H]\u2013[Fe/Zn] relationship in the 2DAs, we derived <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn91.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{stars}}\\sim 2\\times {10}^{10}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{stars}}\\sim 2\\times {10}^{10}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn92.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>. Therefore, the IMS host galaxy appears to be a metal-rich and relatively massive object containing large amounts of dust and neutral gas. In this scenario, star formation is likely to occur.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab08f0s6\" name=\"apjab08f0s6\">6.\u00a0Conclusions</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>This paper mainly reports on optical follow-up observations of the gravitationally lensed quasar SDSS J1442+4055 using the GTC and LT. The main lensing galaxy, G1, is only 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />38 from the brightest quasar image, A, and its GTC spectra clearly show the Ca <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> HK, <em>G</em>-band, H<em>\u03b2</em>, and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> <em>b</em> absorption features at <em>z</em><sub>G1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.284\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001. The new spectra of G1 with unprecedented quality might be used (together with IR spectroscopy) to fit stellar population models in the nonlocal early-type galaxy (e.g., Bruzual <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib7\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib7\">2003</a>). This should lead to realistic microlens mass functions to generate microlensing magnification maps. The secondary galaxies G2 and G3 are located 5<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2 and 33<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />9 from A, and our LT spectra of these two objects yield redshifts <em>z</em><sub>G2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>z</em><sub>G3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01. Thus, G2 is not physically associated with G1, but it is at the same distance as G3.</p><p>The LT <em>r</em>-band light curves of the two quasar images A and B over 2.7 yr of monitoring display significant variations, which are used to measure a time delay of 25.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.5 days (1<em>\u03c3</em> confidence interval; A is leading). Despite this delay being robustly measured to 6% precision, before using it to estimate cosmological parameters, one must consider a possible microlensing-induced contribution (Tie &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib64\">2018</a>). To properly account for a putative microlensing bias in the time-delay estimation, it is required to perform numerical simulations. However, there are reasons to think this bias is well below the delay uncertainty of 1.5 days. First, we detect microlensing magnification gradients &lt;10<sup>\u22124</sup> mag day<sup>\u22121</sup> in the <em>r</em> band. Second, the flux ratios <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> from the GTC spectra of both quasar images do not show evidence of microlensing inhomogeneous magnification, since sources with different shapes/sizes are magnified equally.</p><p>Current observational constraints also allow us to explore simple mass models for SDSS J1442+4055 and thus compare the predicted delays with the measured one. We may consider the astrometry in Table 1 of Sergeyev et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>) and the lens magnification ratio we derive in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s4\">4</a>, i.e., a macrolens flux ratio <em>B</em>/<em>A</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.64\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.064, where the uncertainty is increased to 10% to take an unknown microlens effect into account. If we fit a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) mass model to these observations (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn93.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}\\sim $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}\\sim</script></span></span> 0), the LENSMODEL software (Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib30\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib31\">2010</a>) produces an Einstein radius, ellipticity (position angle), and time delay of 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />073, 0.034 (\u221228<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />0), and 26 days (adopting the concordance cosmology we use in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s4\">4</a>; Komatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib33\">2009</a>). As the ellipticity of the SIE model is quite small, we could also probe a singular isothermal sphere (SIS), where the position of the SIS is allowed to vary during the fitting procedure. Through the LENSMODEL package, we find a solution with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn94.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}</script></span></span>\u00a0=<em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0=\u00a02.45/2. The lensing mass parameters are 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />078 (Einstein radius) and (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn95.gif\" alt=\"${x}_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{x}_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn96.gif\" alt=\"${y}_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{y}_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span>)\u00a0=\u00a0(1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />339, \u22120<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />323), with the lens center being slightly offset (~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />02) from Sergeyev et al.'s position of G1. This SIS model leads to a time delay of 25.3 days, which is very close to our central delay value (see above).</p><p>The GTC quasar spectra indicate the presence of an IMS at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02, and we measure <em>z</em><sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465 from strong metal absorption lines in the SDSS-BOSS spectrum of A, which has a higher resolution than those of the GTC (see also Sergeyev et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib58\">2016</a>; Krogager et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>). Leaving aside absorption features, the high-S/N spectroscopy with the GTC offers a unique opportunity to analyze the flux ratios <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> over the wide wavelength interval between 3430 and 9250 \u00c5. A prominent extinction bump is detected at a redshift similar to that of the distant IMS, so this high-<em>z</em> object contains dust grains and gas-phase metals. Assuming that dust properties are similar along both sight lines (A and B), we fit extinction curves to the magnitude differences from the measured flux ratios. At <em>z</em><sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465, the transverse distance between A and B is less than 1 kpc. In addition, \u00d8stman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib51\">2008</a>) reported that when several images of the same quasar are affected by dust extinction, the preferred values of <em>R</em>(<em>V</em>) are similar. A general Galactic extinction curve (Cardelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib8\">1989</a>) yields an acceptable fit with <em>R</em>(<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a02.672\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.048 and a differential visual extinction <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn97.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)-{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)-{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.133\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 mag. Moreover, using the extinction law of Fitzpatrick &amp; Massa (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">1990</a>), we obtain <em>x</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a04.527\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.004 <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>\u03b3</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02 <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> for the central wavenumber and width (FWHM) of the extinction bump. The value of <em>x</em><sub>0</sub> is very unusual in the MW, but it agrees with the values in the LMC and metal-rich absorbers at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132 (e.g., Gordon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib24\">2003</a>; Fitzpatrick &amp; Massa <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib20\">2007</a>; Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib43\">2017</a>).</p><p>To accurately study the gas content of the high-<em>z</em> IMS and the dust\u2013gas correlation, we use the GTC spectra of A and B, as well as higher-resolution data from the SDSS-BOSS spectroscopy of A and the MMT observations of both quasar images (Findlay et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib18\">2018</a>). Assuming that the dust grain column density is proportional to the H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> column density, the visual extinction ratio <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn98.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)/{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)/{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)</script></span></span> = <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn99.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn100.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~ 1.6 enables us to know how dust affects each individual image. For example, we estimate bump strengths of 0.47 (A) and 0.76 (B) mag <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup>. These are consistent with bump areas in the LMC and metal-rich absorbers at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132 (e.g., Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib43\">2017</a>). The IMS at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 belongs to the family of dusty absorbers discussed by Ma et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib42\">2018</a>), since it is a metal-strong subDLA/DLA system with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn101.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0~\u00a020.0\u201320.5, contains C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> gas with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn102.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,N</script></span></span>(C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0&gt;14.0, and has high values of the dust-to-gas ratio <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>)/<em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) (~1.6\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>\u221221</sup> mag cm<sup>2</sup>), the gas-phase metallicity indicator [Zn/H] (~+0.3; H \u2261H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>), and the dust depletion level (\u22121.5\u00a0&lt;\u00a0[Fe/Zn]\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u22121). Our results in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t7\">7</a> and Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f9\">9</a> can also be used to check the variation in metal-line EW over a transverse physical scale of ~0.7 kpc (e.g., Koyamada et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib35\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib35\">2017</a>; Rubin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib56\">2018</a>). Finally, we note that this work and a spectroscopic study of SDSS J1442+4055 by Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>) have been conducted concurrently but independently. Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>) used Keck spectra and data analysis methods different from ours to obtain results similar to those we present here.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank the anonymous referee for helpful comments that contributed to improving the final version of the paper. The Liverpool Telescope is operated on the island of La Palma by Liverpool John Moores University in the Spanish Observatorio del Roque de los Muchachos of the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias with financial support from the UK Science and Technology Facilities Council. This article is also based on observations made with the Gran Telescopio Canarias, installed at the Spanish Observatorio del Roque de los Muchachos of the Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Canarias on the island of La Palma. We thank the staff of both telescopes for kind interaction before, during, and after the observations. We also used data taken from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) database. The SDSS is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration. The SDSS website is <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\">www.sdss.org</a>. Funding for the SDSS has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, and national agencies in the U.S. and other countries. The SDSS acknowledges support and resources from the Center for High-Performance Computing at the University of Utah. We are grateful to the SDSS collaboration for doing that public database. This research has been conducted in the framework of the Gravitational LENses and DArk MAtter (GLENDAMA) project, which was/is supported by Spanish Department of Research, Development and Innovation grant AYA2013-47744-C3-2-P; MINECO/AEI/FEDER-UE grant AYA2017-89815-P; the complementary action \"Lentes Gravitatorias y Materia Oscura\" financed by the SOciedad para el DEsarrollo Regional de CANtabria (SODERCAN S.A.); the Operational Programme of FEDER-UE; and the University of Cantabria.</p><p><em>Facilities:</em> Liverpool:2m(IO:O and SPRAT), GTC(OSIRIS).</p><p><em>Software:</em> IRAF (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://iraf.noao.edu/\">http://iraf.noao.edu/</a>), PyRAF (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/institute/software_hardware/pyraf\">http://www.stsci.edu/institute/software_hardware/pyraf</a>), SciPy (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.scipy.org/\">https://www.scipy.org/</a>), Astropy (Astropy Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib4\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib5\">2018</a>), Linetools (Prochaska et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib55\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib55\">2017</a>), IMFITFITS (McLeod et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib44\">1998</a>), VoigtFit (Krogager <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib36\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib36\">2018</a>), LENSMODEL (Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib30\">2001</a>).</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab08f0fn1\" id=\"apjab08f0fn1\">4\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Program ID: 14127; This is publicly available at <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://github.com/profxj/linetools\">https://github.com/profxj/linetools</a>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab08f0fn6\" From the LT light curves between 2015 December and 2018 August, we derive at once a time delay of 25.0 \u00b1 1.5 days (1\u03c3 confidence interval; A is leading) and microlensing magnification gradients below 10<SUP>-4</SUP> mag day<SUP>-1</SUP>. The delay interval is not expected to be affected by an appreciable microlensing-induced bias, so it can be used to estimate cosmological parameters. This paper also focuses on new Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC) and LT spectroscopic observations of the lens system. We determine the redshift of two bright galaxies around the doubly imaged quasar using LT spectroscopy, while GTC data lead to low-noise individual spectra of A, B, and the main lensing galaxy, G1. The G1 spectral shape is accurately matched to an early-type galaxy template at z = 0.284, and it has potential for further relevant studies. Additionally, the quasar spectra show absorption by metal-rich gas at z \u223c 2. This dusty absorber is responsible for an extinction bump at a rest-frame wavelength of 2209 \u00b1 2 \u00c5, which has strengths of \u223c0.47 and 0.76 mag \u03bcm<SUP>-1</SUP> for A and B, respectively. In such an intervening system, the dust-to-gas ratio, gas-phase metallicity indicator [Zn/H], and dust depletion level [Fe/Zn] are relatively high.", "start_page": "117", "authors": ["Shalyapin, Vyacheslav N.", "Goicoechea, Luis J."], "issn": "0004-637X", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1903.06505", "Title": "Gravitationally Lensed Quasar SDSS J1442+4055: Redshifts of Lensing Galaxies, Time Delay, Microlensing Variability, and Intervening Metal System at z \u223c 2", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["galaxies: high-redshift", "gravitational lensing: strong", "quasars: individual: SDSS J1442+4055", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJ...873..117S", "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "873", "number": "2", "publication_year": "2019/03/1", "doi": "10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0", "author_address": ["AA(O.Ya. itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\">\n        <a name=\"\" id=\"skip-to-content-link-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n        <div class=\"wrapper grid-3-col da-showgrid ta-showgrid cf\">\n    <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Gravitationally Lensed Quasar SDSS J1442+4055: Redshifts of Lensing Galaxies, Time Delay, Microlensing Variability, and Intervening Metal System at <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a02</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Vyacheslav N. Shalyapin</span><sup>1,2,3</sup></span> and <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Luis J. Goicoechea</span><sup>2</sup><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0110-834X\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0110-834X\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg></a></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2019 March 12</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2019. The American Astronomical Society. All rights reserved.</span><br />\n    <!-- end Copyright -->\n<span itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\" itemid=\"periodical\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-title article-toolbar-anchor\">\n\t<span itemprop=\"name\">\n\t\t<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">The Astrophysical Journal</a></span></span>,\n\t<span itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationVolume\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-vol nowrap\">\n\t<link itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemid=\"periodical\" itemscope/>\n\t<span itemprop=\"volumeNumber\"><a href=\"/volume/0004-637X/873\" itemprop=\"url\">Volume 873</a></span></span>,\n<span itemprop=\"issueNumber\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-issue\"><a href=\"/issue/0004-637X/873/2\" itemprop=\"url\"><!--Issue Number Tile Start-->\nNumber 2<!--Issue Number Tile End--></a></span>\n<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile End-->\n<!-- Start Focus issue title -->\n\t<!-- End focus issue title -->\n\t<span style=\"display: block\"><b>Citation</b> Vyacheslav N.
