}_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{A}}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{A}}}^{2}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">25.2<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${}_{-1.7}^{+1.1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{}_{-1.7}^{+1.1}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{B}}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{B}}}^{2}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">26.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.3</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{4,2}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{4,2}^{2}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">26.3<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${}_{-1.2}^{+3.5}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{}_{-1.2}^{+3.5}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note. </strong>Here <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Delta }}{t}_{\\mathrm{AB}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Delta }}{t}_{\\mathrm{AB}}</script></span></span> is in days, A is leading, and all measurements are 68% confidence intervals.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t5_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t5_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Regarding the magnitude offsets, we derived the 1<em>\u03c3</em> intervals\u2014\u0394<em>m</em><sub>AB</sub>(2016)\u00a0=\u00a00.934\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002 mag, \u0394<em>m</em><sub>AB</sub>(2017)\u00a0=\u00a00.956\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002 mag, and \u0394<em>m</em><sub>AB</sub>(2018)\u00a0=\u00a00.966\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 mag\u2014 and we unambiguously detected microlensing-induced magnification gradients of 0.022\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 mag (between 2016 and 2017) and 0.010\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.004 mag (between 2017 and 2018). From the central values in the time delay and magnitude-offset intervals, we plotted the combined light curve in the <em>r</em> band; i.e., the A brightness record and the magnitude- and time-shifted light curve of B are drawn together (see the bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f5\">5</a>). We remark that by exclusively including seasonal changes in the <em>r</em>-band magnification ratio \u0394<em>m</em><sub>AB</sub>, the shapes of <em>m</em><sub>A</sub>(<em>t</em>) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"${m}_{{\\rm{B}}}(t+{\\rm{\\Delta }}{t}_{\\mathrm{AB}})-{\\rm{\\Delta }}{m}_{\\mathrm{AB}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{m}_{{\\rm{B}}}(t+{\\rm{\\Delta }}{t}_{\\mathrm{AB}})-{\\rm{\\Delta }}{m}_{\\mathrm{AB}}</script></span></span> agree well with each other.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab08f0s4\" name=\"apjab08f0s4\">4.\u00a0Dust Extinction in a High-<em>z</em> Galaxy</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>For a double quasar, spectroscopic observations at two epochs separated by approximately the time delay between its two images lead to delay-corrected flux ratios at different wavelengths, which are valuable tools to study the macro- and microlens magnification ratios, as well as the differential dust extinction (e.g., Schneider et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib57\">2006</a>). Our LT <em>r</em>-band monitoring of SDSS J1442+4055 yields a relatively short delay of about 25 days (A is leading; see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s3\">3</a>), and we have checked that 25 days after the GTC-OSIRIS observations, the LT <em>r</em>-band flux of B only increased by ~1%. Additionally, the LT <em>r</em>-band flux of A at the GTC-OSIRIS observing epoch also increased by ~1% compared to its value 25 days before (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f2\">2</a>). Thus, considering calibration uncertainties and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"${{eF}}_{\\lambda }/{F}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{eF}}_{\\lambda }/{F}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> values at red wavelengths, GTC-OSIRIS single-epoch flux ratios in the red spectral region seem to be plausible tracers of those corrected by intrinsic variability. Despite the spectra of SDSS J1442+4055AB being taken on a single night, we assumed that these data allow us to build flux ratios <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> describing the delay-corrected ones reasonably well. In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>, we present the single-epoch flux ratios from the GTC-OSIRIS spectra, which can be compared with the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn41.gif\" alt=\"${A}^{\\star }/{B}^{\\star }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}^{\\star }/{B}^{\\star }</script></span></span> values in the top panel of Figure 2 of Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>). Here contamination by light from G1 is denoted with a star superscript.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Flux ratios and magnitude differences from the GTC-OSIRIS spectra. Left: full spectra of the quasar images by combining the R500B and R500R data (top) and the corresponding flux ratios between 3430 and 9250 \u00c5 (bottom). Right: magnitude differences (data) and best fits of different extinction laws. We consider dust at <em>z</em><sub>dust</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465 and six extinction scenarios: average MW (MW), average LMC (LMC), average LMC2 supershell (LMC2), average SMC bar (SMC), general MW (CCM), and <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">FM90</a> (see main text for details). Very noisy regions (gray line; see the small vertical bars indicating absorption features) are not fitted to extinction laws.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab08f0f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab08f0f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> data are very noisy at the shortest wavelengths, i.e., on the blue edge of the R500B grism (see the bottom subpanel in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>), which is partially due to the presence of a forest of absorption lines. Additional absorption features at longer wavelengths also produce spikes in <em>B</em>/<em>A</em>. However, in spectral intervals associated with broad line-emitting regions, no significant deviations are found with respect to adjacent continuum flux ratios. This suggests that chromatic microlensing is absent, since compact and extended emitting regions are magnified likewise. Therefore, we adopted a constant lens magnification ratio (including both a macrolens effect caused by the entire mass of the gravitational deflectors and a microlens effect produced by stars in intervening galaxies), so the chromatic behavior of <em>B</em>/<em>A</em> is interpreted as due to dust extinction.</p><p>Apart from absorption-induced artifacts, the most dramatic feature in the flux ratio profile is a broad valley around <em>\u03bb</em>\u00a0~6400 \u00c5, which is likely related to the 2175 \u00c5 extinction bump seen in some galaxies of the Local Group (e.g., Gordon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib24\">2003</a>), lensing galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01 (e.g., Mediavilla et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib45\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib45\">2005</a>), and several metal-rich absorbers at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 (e.g., Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib43\">2017</a>). The existence of this bump is critical to deciding about the redshift of the intervening dust. Thus, we roughly obtained <em>z</em><sub>dust</sub>\u00a0~\u00a01.94, in good agreement with <em>z</em><sub>IMS</sub>. The main lensing galaxy G1 does not seem to play a relevant role in extinction, and the high-<em>z</em> IMS would be primarily responsible for the chromaticity observed in <em>B</em>/<em>A</em>. In fact, there is no appreciable absorption at <em>z</em><sub>G1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.284 in the quasar spectra, while both spectra are clearly absorbed at <em>z</em><sub>IMS</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f7\">7</a> does not show any significant distortion of the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> profiles at <em>\u03bb</em>\u00a0=\u00a03590 \u00c5, where the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2796 line would have been seen if Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption had occurred in G1.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line profiles of A and B from the GTC-OSIRIS and MMT spectra. The thick solid lines are the Voigt functions (convolved with Gaussian instrumental responses) that best fit the GTC-OSIRIS and MMT normalized fluxes in the nonshaded wavelength interval, and the dashed lines represent their 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties. Left: profiles of image A. The SDSS normalized fluxes are included only for comparison purposes, since the SDSS-BOSS spectrum exclusively covers the red wing of the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line. Right: profiles of image B.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadFigure/figure/apjab08f0f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab08f0f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab08f0f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We converted flux ratios into magnitude differences, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn42.gif\" alt=\"${m}_{{\\rm{B}}}-{m}_{{\\rm{A}}}\\,=\\,-2.5\\mathrm{log}(B/A)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{m}_{{\\rm{B}}}-{m}_{{\\rm{A}}}\\,=\\,-2.5\\mathrm{log}(B/A)</script></span></span>, and then used several extinction laws to fit these differences (e.g., Falco et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib16\">1999</a>; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib14\">2006</a>). For <em>z</em><sub>dust</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465, we are probing the UV extinction in the distant dusty galaxy, i.e., at rest-frame wavelengths between 1165 and 3140 \u00c5. This spectral range practically coincides with the wavelength coverage of the low-dispersion mode of the <em>International Ultraviolet Explorer</em> satellite, which provided a wealth of data on the UV extinction of close stars (e.g., Fitzpatrick &amp; Massa <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">1990</a>). According to concordance cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub><em>m</em></sub>\u00a0=0.27, and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.73 (Komatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib33\">2009</a>), the transverse distance between the two light paths at <em>z</em><sub>dust</sub> (Smette et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib62\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib62\">1992</a>; Cooke et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib9\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib9\">2010</a>) is only ~0.7 kpc (see also Krogager et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>). We implicitly assumed that the dust properties are the same along the lines of sight to both images. In addition, we did not fit the noisy magnitude differences at the shortest wavelengths or a series of spikes caused by absorption features at longer wavelengths (see the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>).</p><p>First, we considered the average extinction curve of the Milky Way (MW; Cardelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib8\">1989</a>), as well as average curves for other objects in the Local Group (Gordon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib24\">2003</a>): the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC), LMC2 supershell (LMC2), and Small Magellanic Cloud bar (SMC). Our data are quite inconsistent with the average extinction curves of the LMC2 and SMC (green and red lines in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>) and show a behavior halfway between the average curves for the LMC and MW (orange and blue lines in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>). Second, we obtained a significant improvement in the reduced <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> value when fitting a general Galactic extinction law (Cardelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib8\">1989</a>, hereafter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib8\">CCM</a>). This CCM relationship led to a lens magnification ratio of 0.490\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005 mag (the constant term in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn43.gif\" alt=\"${m}_{{\\rm{B}}}-{m}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{m}_{{\\rm{B}}}-{m}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>), a differential visual extinction <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn44.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Delta }}{A}_{\\mathrm{AB}}(V)={A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)-{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Delta }}{A}_{\\mathrm{AB}}(V)={A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)-{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)</script></span></span> of 0.133\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 mag, and a total-to-selective extinction ratio <em>R</em>(<em>V</em>) of 2.672\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.048 (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn45.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}=3.77$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}=3.77</script></span></span>; purple line in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>).</p><p>As a final step, in order to accurately describe the observed bump, data were fitted by the wavelength-dependent function of Fitzpatrick &amp; Massa (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">1990</a>, hereafter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">FM90</a>). <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">FM90</a> introduced a Drude (Lorentzian-like) profile for representing a bump with central wavenumber <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"${x}_{0}=1/{\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{x}_{0}=1/{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span> and width (FWHM) <em>\u03b3</em>, and <em>x</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a04.527\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.004 <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>\u03b3</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.99\u00a0\u00b10.02 <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> were obtained from the fit (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}=3.30$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}=3.30</script></span></span>; brown line in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>). In the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f6\">6</a>, the residuals of the purple and brown lines have amplitudes similar to those of the observed noise. Hence, although our best <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{{\\rm{r}}}^{2}</script></span></span> values for the <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib8\">CCM</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib19\">FM90</a> extinction laws are clearly greater than 1, formal uncertainties in magnitude differences may be underestimated by a factor ~2. While the value of <em>\u03b3</em> is typical for sight lines toward Galactic stars, the central wavelength of the extinction bump (<em>\u03bb</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02209 \u00b1 2 \u00c5) is extraordinarily unusual in the MW (e.g., Fitzpatrick &amp; Massa <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib20\">2007</a>). However, values of <em>x</em><sub>0</sub> close to 4.53 <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> are consistent with measurements in the LMC (e.g., Gordon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib24\">2003</a>) and some metal-rich absorbers at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132 (e.g., Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib43\">2017</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab08f0s5\" name=\"apjab08f0s5\">5.\u00a0High-<em>z</em> Gas and Its Correlation with Dust</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s5-1\" name=\"apjab08f0s5-1\">5.1.\u00a0Complementary Observations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To analyze the gas content of the IMS is of interest not only in the use of the low-resolution GTC-OSIRIS spectra of both quasar images (resolving power of ~300\u2013400; see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s2-2\">2.2</a>) but also other available, not previously analyzed medium-resolution spectroscopic data. This higher resolution allows us to identify finer spectral details, e.g., resolve blended absorption lines. Therefore, in addition to the GTC-OSIRIS data, we used the SDSS-BOSS spectrum of the A image with a resolving power of ~2000, as well as the data that were obtained at the MMT Observatory with the Blue Channel Spectrograph (Findlay et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib18\">2018</a>). The MMT spectra of A and B on 2015 June 14 cover a wavelength range of 3500\u20135500 \u00c5 at a spectral resolution of ~1800, which is about 5 times higher than those of the R500B and R500R grisms. For each spectrum, we fitted a global continuum and obtained normalized fluxes using the Linetools software.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab08f0fn5\">8</a></sup>\n\n</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s5-2\" name=\"apjab08f0s5-2\">5.2.\u00a0Neutral Hydrogen</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The GTC-OSIRIS and MMT spectra cover the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> absorption at <em>z</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465, which is observed around 3582 \u00c5. Regarding the GTC-OSIRIS spectra, the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line profile of the B image is deeper and wider than that of the A image, and this suggests a larger H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> column density along the line of sight to B. Using both data sets at different spectral resolutions, we fitted line profiles to a Voigt function convolved with a Gaussian instrumental profile (Krogager <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib36\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib36\">2018</a>). These fits were performed with the VoigtFit software.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab08f0fn6\">9</a></sup>\n In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f7\">7</a>, we show the best fits (thick solid lines) along with their 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties (dashed lines). We note that the fits were done by minimizing <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> in the interval 3560\u00a0\u00c5 \u2264\u00a0<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u22643596 \u00c5 (central, nonshaded region in the two panels of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f7\">7</a>), so that we avoided the Si <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> 1206 line and another prominent absorption feature at <em>\u03bb</em><sub>obs</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03603 \u00c5. Furthermore, in order to estimate 1<em>\u03c3</em> confidence intervals, we used 1000 repetitions of each Ly<em>\u03b1</em> profile. To obtain a repetition of an original Ly<em>\u03b1</em> profile, we modified the normalized observed fluxes by adding realizations of normal distributions around zero, with standard deviations equal to the measured errors.</p><p>The GTC-OSIRIS and MMT data yield the neutral-hydrogen column densities in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t6\">6</a>. It is evident that both measures of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) differ by ~0.2, which is an order of magnitude larger than the formal errors. Thus, we adopted a statistical approach, considering the two values in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t6\">6</a> (20.490 and 20.279) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) from the rest-frame equivalent width (EW) of the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line in the MMT spectrum of B (20.26; see Equation (9.24) of Draine <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib13\">2011</a>). Calculating the average value and its standard deviation, and taking into account that the standard deviation of the mean of three values is 50% uncertain, we obtain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0=\u00a020.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11. From the two values of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t6\">6</a>, we also infer <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0=\u00a020.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11, where the error of the mean was conservatively enlarged to 0.11. The IMS can be classified as a subdamped/damped Ly<em>\u03b1</em> (subDLA/DLA) system (Wolfe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib69\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib69\">1986</a>), and our H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> column densities agree (although having larger uncertainties) with those from the high-resolution Keck-HIRES spectra of the quasar at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$\\lambda \\lt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lambda \\lt</script></span></span> 6000 \u00c5 on 2017 May 20 (Krogager et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t6\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 6.</b>\u00a0\nNeutral-hydrogen Column Densities\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0t6\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t6_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 6\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Facility</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\,{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">GTC-OSIRIS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">20.160\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.021</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">20.490\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.029</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">MMT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">20.130\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.015</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">20.279\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.025</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab08f0t6fna\" id=\"apjab08f0t6fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Column density <em>N</em> in cm<sup>\u22122</sup>.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t6_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab08f0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/873/2/117/suppdata/apjab08f0t6_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s5-3\" name=\"apjab08f0s5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Dust-to-gas Ratio</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The visual extinction <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>) is proportional to the optical depth at <em>\u03bb</em><sub>rest</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.55 <em>\u03bc</em>m, which in turn is proportional to the dust grain column density <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"$N(\\mathrm{dust})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">N(\\mathrm{dust})</script></span></span>. Assuming that <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"$N(\\mathrm{dust})\\propto N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">N(\\mathrm{dust})\\propto N</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) (e.g., Fall &amp; Pei <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib17\">1989</a>; Zuo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib72\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib72\">1997</a>), we then obtained <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)/{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)/{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)</script></span></span> = <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{B}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{B}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{A}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{A}}}</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~1.6 (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5-2\">5.2</a>). From this visual extinction ratio and the differential visual extinction in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s4\">4</a>, it is possible to estimate the effect of dust along each line of sight: <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)\\sim 0.22$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{{\\rm{A}}}(V)\\sim 0.22</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)\\sim 0.35$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{{\\rm{B}}}(V)\\sim 0.35</script></span></span> mag. We remark upon the similarity between these individual extinctions and the <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>) values found in Krogager et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib37\">2018</a>). The color excesses of the individual images would be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"${E}_{{\\rm{A}}}(B-V)\\sim 0.08$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{E}_{{\\rm{A}}}(B-V)\\sim 0.08</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"${E}_{{\\rm{B}}}(B-V)\\sim 0.13$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{E}_{{\\rm{B}}}(B-V)\\sim 0.13</script></span></span> mag; thus, the bump strength (area of the extinction bump) may be estimated at 0.47 and 0.76 mag <em>\u03bc</em>m<sup>\u22121</sup> for A and B, respectively. These strengths agree well with those of the LMC and metal-rich absorbers at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132, whereas they are weaker than most measures in the MW (see Figure 1 of Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib43\">2017</a>).</p><p>The ratio between <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>) (or <em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>)) and <em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) is usually called the dust-to-gas ratio (e.g., Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib42\">2018</a> and references therein). For the IMS of SDSS J1442+4055, we derived <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>)/<em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>)\u00a0~\u00a01.6\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>\u221221</sup> mag cm<sup>2</sup>, and such a high value is also observed in some absorbers with high metallicity (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5-5\">5.5</a>). This dust-to-gas ratio is a factor of ~3 higher than that of the local interstellar medium (Liszt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib40\">2014</a>) and the MW average visual extinction per H for <em>R</em>(<em>V</em>)\u00a0~\u00a02.7 (see Figure 3 of Draine <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib12\">2003</a>), as well as about 5 times higher than the mean ratio of the LMC and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorbers (Gordon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib24\">2003</a>; M\u00e9nard &amp; Chelouche <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib47\">2009</a>). Moreover, the mean ratio of high-<em>z</em> DLAs is nearly two orders of magnitude lower than the <em>A</em>(<em>V</em>)/<em>N</em>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) value for the IMS (Vladilo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib67\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib67\">2008</a>). Lastly, it is worth mentioning that <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"$E(B-V)/N$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">E(B-V)/N</script></span></span>(H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) ~ 6\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>\u221222</sup> mag cm<sup>2</sup>, which is similar to the corresponding ratio of the distant lensing galaxy of SBS 0909+532 (Dai &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib10\">2009</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab08f0s5-4\" name=\"apjab08f0s5-4\">5.4.\u00a0Metals</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In addition to neutral hydrogen, quasar spectra are affected by metals at <em>z</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9465. Prominent metal lines are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab08f0f8\">8</a>, which incorporates data from the SDSS-BOSS (gray; only for A), GTC-OSIRIS (red for A and blue for B), and MMT Observatory (magenta for A and cyan for B). The GTC-OSIRIS line profiles were then used to determine the rest-frame EWs of absorption lines at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\geqslant 5500$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\geqslant 5500</script></span></span> \u00c5, whereas the EWs of lines observed at shorter wavelengths were derived from the MMT profiles (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab08f0s5-1\">5.1</a>). The EWs of the main absorption features are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t7\">7</a>. The neutral-carbon detection is particularly interesting, since the appearance of a 2175 \u00c5 extinction bump at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 has been linked to the presence of C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (e.g., El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib21\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib21\">2009</a>; Ledoux et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib38\">2015</a>; Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab08f0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab08f0bib42\">2018</a>). We observe strong absorption (EW\u00a0&gt;\u00a01 \u00c5) of C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1328 and weaker lines of C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1277, C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1560, and C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 1656. We also note the presence of Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026. Despite the Zn II 2026 and Mg I 2026 lines are blended with each other, EW(Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026) values are presented in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab08f0t7\">7</a>. We used the correction EW(Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026)\u00a0=\u00a0EW(Zn <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2026+Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2026) \u2212 [<em>f</em>(Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2026)/<em>f</em>(Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2852)]<b>&#x00d7;</b>EW(Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2852), where <em>f</em>(Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2026) and <em>f</em>(Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> 2852) are oscillator strengths.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab08f0f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab08f0f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/873/2/117/Full/apjab08f0f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Prominent metal absorption lines due to the IMS toward SDSS J1442+4055. Profiles of A are marked in gray (SDSS-BOSS data), red (GTC-OSIRIS data), and magenta (MMT data), and profiles of B are marked in blue (GTC-OSIRIS data) and cyan (MMT data).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab08f0f8\" image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab08f0t7\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 7.</b>\u00a0\nRest-frame EWs of the
